member.name: IMediaEvent.CancelDefaultHandling

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The CancelDefaultHandling method cancels the Filter Graph Manager's default handling for a specified event. The event notification is passed to the application.

member.param: Event code for which to cancel default handling.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value. Possible values include those shown in the following table.

listheader.description: No default handling for this event.

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The FreeEventParams method frees resources associated with the parameters of an event.

member.name: IMediaEvent.GetEvent

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The GetEvent method retrieves the next event notification from the event queue.

member.param: Pointer to a variable that receives the event code.
Pointer to a variable that receives the first event parameter.
Pointer to a variable that receives the second event parameter.
Time-out interval, in milliseconds. Use INFINITE to block until there is an event.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value. Possible values include those shown in the following table.

member.name: IMediaEvent.GetEventHandle

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The GetEventHandle method retrieves a handle to a manual-reset event that remains signaled while the queue contains event notifications.

member.param: Pointer to a variable that receives the event handle.

member.name: IMediaEvent.RestoreDefaultHandling

The RestoreDefaultHandling method restores the Filter Graph Manager's default handling for a specified event.

member.param: Event code for which to restore default handling.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value. Possible values include the following.

listheader.description: No default handling for this event.

member.name: IMediaEvent.WaitForCompletion

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The WaitForCompletion method waits for the filter graph to render all available data. The filter graph must be running or the method fails.

member.param: Time-out interval, in milliseconds. Pass zero to return immediately. Pass the value INFINITE to block indefinitely.
Pointer to a variable that receives an event code. See Remarks for more information.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value. Possible values include the following.

listheader.description: The filter graph is not running.

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]

The IMediaEvent interface contains methods for retrieving event notifications and for overriding the Filter Graph Manager's default handling of events. The interface inherits this interface and extends it.

The Filter Graph Manager implements this interface. Applications can use it to respond to events that occur in the filter graph, such as the end of a stream or a rendering error. Filters post events to the filter graph using the interface.
For more information about event notification, see Event Notification in DirectShow. For a list of system-defined event notifications, see Event Notification Codes.
